comments.body: Perhaps ansible-doc should emit an error if self.options.all_plugins and self.options.module_path are both set?
~~will be noop then depending on which gets merged first, but need to actually be able to tests the cliconf/httpapi plugins~~

I don't think so.... we only have one instance of a loader per run.  So module_path will apply to a loader.  But only one of them.  So we either need to apply it to all of them (I'm not sure if that works... can you have all plugin types in a single loader path?) or we need to error out so the user knows not to use the module_path option with the all_plugins option.

sorry, that comment was meant for the `constants.py` change, i agree on module_path being an issue with --all, but we only use this option internally for CI so i dont see custom paths applicable for this case.
also, code already emits warning that module path is ignored with -a/--all

I did this because the below `os.listdir` failed on https://github.com/ansible/ansible/blob/devel/test/runner/lib/ansible_util.py#L48 in a testing environment. Figured it's a good check to have anyway?

comments.body: should have elif/else with same error on 'non list'

This may not matter because something else may handle the RST --> HTML conversion, but for in RST, `**word**` is the syntax for bold while `*word*` is the syntax for italic. If this is only for the display of `ansible-doc`, this should be fine. But it'd be surprising if `B(word)` ended up being italic in the final HTML.

rst and html (for building the web docs) are handled by rst_ify and html_ify from this code: https://github.com/ansible-community/antsibull/blob/main/antsibull/jinja2/filters.py

The code in this PR is only for ansible-doc to output to the screen.

This split is why I added the note that the code in both places needs to be changed if new macros are added.
Ah, ok. I figured they were separate and this was only for `ansible-doc` output. I just wanted to make sure.
Fun times with cross project relationships. 😁

        t = cls._ITALIC.sub(r"`\1'", text)    # I(word) => `word'
        t = cls._BOLD.sub(r"*\1*", t)         # B(word) => *word*
        t = cls._MODULE.sub("[" + r"\1" + "]", t)       # M(word) => [word]
        t = cls._URL.sub(r"\1", t)                      # U(word) => word
